For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A right coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $Ha = \{ha; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
A field is a commutative division ring.
An ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ in a ring $R$ is finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators.
An automorphism of a ring $R$ is an isomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.

For an integral domain $R$, the field of fractions $Q(R)$ is the set of equivalence classes of pairs $(a, b)$ where $a, b \in R$ and $b \neq 0$, under the equivalence relation defined by $(a, b) \sim (a', b')$ if and only if $ab' = a'b$.
A separable polynomial is a polynomial that has distinct roots in its splitting field, i.e., all roots are simple.

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.

A finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\	ext{\_q}\]$ consists of $q$ elements, where $q=p^n$ for some prime number $p$ and integer $n>0$. It is different from the residue class ring $\\[\mathbb{Z} / p^n \mathbb{Z}\]$ for $n>1$, as the latter has nontrivial zero divisors and cannot be a field.
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.

The Klein four-group, denoted as $\mathfrak{V}_{4}$, is a subgroup of $\mathfrak{S}_{4}$ consisting of the permutations $\{\mathrm{id}, (1,2)(3,4), (1,3)(2,4), (1,4)(2,3)\}$. It is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A finite field is a specific type of field characterized by having a finite number of elements. Thus, every finite field is a field, but not every field is finite.
